Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: From Almaty to Astana: Authoritarianism, Nationalism, and Kazakhstan's Capital Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines state strategies and the nature of popular and elite geopolitical culture in Kazakhstan. It highlights the contested nature of the state project to promote a particular vision of national identity in Kazakhstan. The central research questions are: How has the state decision to move the capital to Astana been used to promote a particular "Kazakhstani" identity? And how has this been interpreted by the people of Kazakhstan? In answering these questions, this study will employ both quantitative and qualitative methods, including a country-wide survey (of 1,500 respondents), textual analysis, focus groups, and interviews. Furthermore, the research project will explore the ways in which the citizens of Kazakhstan have actively engaged in the interpretation of the state's identity project. The researcher will also shed light on contestations and multiple articulations of identity in Kazakhstan. The capital city change is used as a focal point for understanding the population's articulations of their identity and their geopolitical imaginations.
The findings of the proposed research will contribute to advancing knowledge by linking theoretical and methodological approaches to the investigation of nationalism of a region currently undergoing significant political changes. The project draws heavily on the regional studies tradition, highlighting the centrality of deep regional knowledge to the generation of theory and empirical field research in geography. Furthermore, Kazakhstan is an important site for this study because Central Asia is a particularly neglected region within the discipline of geography. Although Kazakhstan has a small population of 16 million people with a territorial size of 2.7 million sq km, its strategic significance cannot be underestimated given that the country is home to vast oil and gas reserves and is one of the world's leading producers of uranium ore. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career. This project is jointly supported by the NSF Geography and Spatial Sciences Program and the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is a study of contemporary political geography in Kazakhstan, which gained independence in 1991 when the Soviet Union collapsed. The primary research question is, how has the ruling regime under President Nursultan Nazarbayev asserted its own authority and legitimacy, as well as Kazakhstan’s sovereignty in the post-Soviet era? The intellectual merit of the project is thus to explain the genuine popularity of the nondemocratic regime of Nazarbayev, who has been in power since 1991 – as well as to shed light on authoritarian regime popularity more generally. This goal has the broader impact of helping US policy makers and scholars to understand the domestic politics of Kazakhstan, a country whose strategic significance cannot be underestimated, as noted by US Under Secretary William J. Burns (2009): “Central Asia’s economic growth and political development can produce more reliable partners for combating global challenges, from non-proliferation to counter-narcotics to energy security.” US interests in Central Asia depend on regional stability, so in the case of Kazakhstan, this study has analyzed how this stability is achieved, and whether or not it is sustainable.

The primary output of the research is the co-PI’s doctoral dissertation in Geography at the University of Colorado, Boulder, entitled, “The city and the steppe: Territory, technologies of government, and Kazakhstan’s new capital.” This dissertation employs mixed qualitative and quantitative methods, including data from a country-wide survey (and analyzed through multilevel statistical modeling), interviews, participant observation, focus groups, and textual analysis. It was carried out over the course of 3 field visits to 8 cities in Kazakhstan from June 2009 to July 2011. The project take a case-oriented approach that focuses on Kazakhstan’s new capital city, Astana. The findings of the project suggest that the Nazarbayev regime is legitimately popular in Kazakhstan, largely because, as a “developmental regime,” it has offered its citizens various economic opportunities (primarily through the Astana development project) for which they are extremely grateful. Participants rarely critiqued the extravagant new city’s development, but praised it for giving them a renewed sense of pride in their homeland. The project also found that few Kazakhstanis openly expressed opinions critical of the Nazarbayev regime more generally. The co-PI found that this was largely because people simply lack a vocabulary for expressing themselves outside of the official state-sanctioned mode. However, the lack of critique is mostly attributable to the fact that many people are pleased with the state of affairs in their country – especially in comparison to their troubled neighbors (e.g. Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan). In addition to this satisfaction with the dramatically improved living conditions since the late 1990s, people are simply not taught or encouraged to think about politics as a matter of their personal concern, because the Nazarbayev regime is understood to be doing a good job of looking after them. The government has thus managed to preclude alternative views that would challenge its position of power through many positive measures, including foreign policy achievements projected inward, providing extensive education and job opportunities, creating new and pervasive sources of pleasure (such as shopping, leisure, festivals, cultural events, etc.) that were not available during the Soviet Union or in the 1990s. Citizens today feel increasingly proud to identify themselves as Kazakh or Kazakhstani – and the government has successfully managed to portray itself as the vehicle of making this a reality.
